McArthur, George Fisher Baker Professor of Administration, Emeritus] {{HBSDean}} {{Bell Canada}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McArthur, John H.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:People from Burnaby]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Business School faculty]] [[Category:University of British Columbia alumni]] [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Business school deans]]

{{For|the Yale University coach|John J. Mack (coach)}} {{For|the African-American civic leader|John Mack (civic leader)}} {{Infobox person | name = John J. Mack | image = | caption = | party = Republican | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1944|11|17}} | birth_place = [[Mooresville, North Carolina]], U.S. | other_names = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Duke University]] | nationality = American | occupation = Banker | years_active = 1967-present | known_for = Chairman, [[Morgan Stanley]]
(Jun 30, 2005 - Jan 1, 2012)
CEO, [[Credit Suisse]]
(2001 - 2004)
CEO, [[Morgan Stanley]]
(Jun 30, 2005 - Jan 1, 2010)
Senior Advisor, [[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts|KKR]]
(2012-present) | spouse = Christy Mack | children = 3 }} '''John J. Mack''' (born November 17, 1944) is a Senior Advisor and the former CEO & Chairman of the Board at [[Morgan Stanley]], the [[New York City|New York]]-based [[investment bank]] and [[brokerage]] firm.{{cite news|last1=Angelova|first1=Kamelia|title=The Legendary Career Of John J. Mack|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/john-j-mack-2009-9?op=1|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=14 September 2009}}{{cite news|last1=Pressler|first1=Jessica|title=Look Who's Back: John Mack is no longer at the top of Morgan Stanley. So he’s getting his fix elsewhere|url=http://nymag.com/news/business/themoney/john-mack-2012-4/|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=8 April 2012}} == Early life and education == Mack was born in [[Mooresville, North Carolina]], the son of Alice (née Azouri) and Charles Mack. Mack's father's original family name was Makhoul; he came to the United States from [[Lebanon]] when he was 12 years old, following Mack's grandfather, who had arrived at [[Ellis Island]] in 1909.{{cite news|last1=Thomas Jr.|first1=Landon|title=From Lebanese-American Financiers, Differing Views on the Strife|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/01/business/worldbusiness/01wall.html|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 August 2006}} The family settled in [[North Carolina]]. Mack's father ran a wholesale grocery, clothing, and general merchandise store called John Mack & Son in [[Mooresville, North Carolina]].{{cite news|title=Madeline Mack (1914-2006)|url=https://mamclothing.com/madelines-influence/|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=Mack and Mack Clothing}} The business occupied The John Mack Building from 1937 to the 1990s.{{cite web|title=Mooresville Historic Walking Tour|url=http://68.71.163.9/walkingtour/WalkingTour.pdf|website=Town of Mooresville|accessdate=13 November 2015}} Mack is the youngest of six sons. The family was Catholic.{{cite web|title=John J. Mack|url=http://www.horatioalger.org/members_info.cfm?memberid=MAC03|website=[[Horatio Alger Association of Distinguished Americans|The Horatio Alger Association]]|accessdate=12 November 2015}} In 1968, Mack graduated from [[Duke University]], where he attended on a [[American football|football]] scholarship and majored in history. Mack's first job in finance was as a clerk at a small brokerage house during his junior year at Duke, after a cracked vertebra made it impossible for him to continue on his football scholarship. == Career == === Morgan Stanley === Mack worked at several firms around Wall Street before starting his career at Morgan Stanley in 1972 as a salesman, and has since worked for the company for nearly thirty years. Rising steadily to positions of increasing responsibility, Mack eventually headed the firm's Worldwide Taxable Fixed Income Division from 1985 to 1992.{{cite news|last1=Carney|first1=John|title=Morgan Stanley Bids John Mack Farewell|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/45587614|accessdate=11 January 2016|work=[[CNBC]]|date=8 December 2011}} In 1987, he became a member of the board of directors. In March 1992, he assumed responsibility for Morgan Stanley's day-to-day operations as chairman of the operating committee. He was named President of Morgan Stanley in June 1993. Mack served as president, chief operating officer and a director of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co. from May 1997 when the firm was created by the merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, two of the world's leading financial services companies.{{cite news|last1=Barboza|first1=David|title=Veteran Executive Is 'Tough And Direct'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/business/veteran-executive-is-tough-and-direct.html|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=6 February 1997}} In 2001, Mack left Morgan Stanley after a power struggle with [[Philip J. Purcell|Phil Purcell]]; Purcell became CEO of Morgan Stanley after the 1997 merger of Morgan Stanley and [[Dean Witter Reynolds|Dean Witter]], of which Purcell was already CEO. === Credit Suisse === Six months later, in June 2001, Mack was hired as CEO of [[Credit Suisse]], then known as [[Credit Suisse First Boston]] (CSFB).{{cite news|last1=McGeehan|first1=Patrick|title=His Rallying Cry at First Boston: Smaller, Cleaner, Fairer|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/01/27/business/his-rallying-cry-at-first-boston-smaller-cleaner-fairer.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 January 2002}} Mack's time at Credit Suisse was marked much restructuring and by compliances issues created by [[Frank Quattrone]]'s Technology Group.{{cite news|last1=Sellers|first1=Patricia|title=The Trials of John Mack|url=http://archive.fortune.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2003/09/01/348191/index.htm|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=1 September 2003}} === Morgan Stanley redux === On June 30, 2005, Mack returned to Morgan Stanley as Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board, replacing Purcell.{{cite news|title=Morgan Stanley's Mack Attack|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/stories/2006-06-20/morgan-stanleys-mack-attackbusinessweek-business-news-stock-market-and-financial-advice|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[Business Week]]|date=20 June 2006}}{{cite news|title=John Mack Elected Chairman and CEO of Morgan Stanley|url=http://www.morganstanley.com/about-us-articles/3685.html|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[Morgan Stanley]]|date=30 June 2005}} Mack was noted for stabilizing the firm and reenergizing its culture and client franchise,{{cite news|last1=Bizouati|first1=Yaël|last2=Basar|first2=Shanny|title=Was Purcell right about Morgan Stanley after all?|url=http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2009-04-06/was-purcell-right-about-morgan-stanley-after-all-1|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[Financial News]]|date=6 April 2009}} despite an economic downturn.{{cite news|last1=Bowley|first1=Graham|title=Red Ink Stains Bank and Banker|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/business/23morgan.html|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=22 July 2009}} Mack announced his retirement as [[Chief Executive Officer]] on September 10, 2009, which was effective January 1, 2010.{{cite news|last1=McFadden|first1=Jeanmarie|last2=Charnas|first2=Suzanne|title=Morgan Stanley Announces CEO Succession Plan|url=http://www.morganstanley.com/about-us-articles/ad3bec19-9e49-11de-b417-0db96b986471.html|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[Morgan Stanley]]|date=10 September 2009}} In 2011, Mack retired from Morgan Stanley{{cite news|last1=Levin|first1=Bess|title=John Mack: If I Wasn’t A Banker, I Would Have Been A Women’s Shoe Salesman|url=http://dealbreaker.com/2011/12/john-mack-if-i-werent-a-banker-i-would-have-been-a-womens-shoe-salesman/|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=Dealbreaker|date=8 December 2011}} after more than 30 years as an investment banker.{{cite news|last1=Rushe|first1=Dominic|title=John Mack, aka Mack the Knife, steps down from Morgan Stanley after 30 years|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/sep/15/mack-knife-morgan-stanley-retires|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=15 September 2011}} Former Co-President [[James P. Gorman]] succeeded him as CEO. === Kohlberg Kravis Roberts === In 2012, Mack joined [[Kohlberg Kravis Roberts]] as a Senior Advisor.{{cite news|last1=De La Merced|first1=Michael J.|title=K.K.R. Hires Mack as Senior Adviser|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/03/27/k-k-r-hires-john-mack-as-senior-adviser/|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=27 March 2012}}{{cite news|last1=Benoit|first1=David|title=Deal Journal: John Mack to Join KKR as Senior Adviser|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2012/03/27/john-mack-to-join-kkr-as-senior-adviser/|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=27 March 2012}} === Rosneft === In 2013 Mack joined [[Rosneft]], the Russian, state-owned, oil company that has BP as an investor of approximately 20%. In 2014 he announced his departure,{{cite news|title=John Mack steps down from Rosneft |url=https://www.ft.com/content/62a05aee-e73c-11e3-aa93-00144feabdc0|accessdate=30 October 2016|work=[[Financial times]]|date=29 May 2014}} shortly after the CEO [[Igor Sechin]] had sanctions imposed upon him by the US. Different reasons were given for his departure; Mack said his contract had only been for a year, while Rosneft spokespeople said he had decided to leave for personal reasons. == Insider trading accusations == In 2006, Mack was accused by former [[United States Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] investigator [[Gary J. Aguirre]] of [[insider trading]].{{cite news|last1=Moyer|first1=Liz|title=SEC Wants Mack|url=https://www.forbes.com/2006/07/21/mack-ubs-sec-fund-cx_lm_0721mack.html|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]|date=21 July 2006}}{{cite news|last1=Morgenson|first1=Gretchen|last2=Bogdanich|first2=Walt|title=Report Says S.E.C. Erred on Pequot|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/04/business/04pequot.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 August 2007}} On October 5, 2006, the SEC recommended no action be taken against Mack. In late November 2006, Mack and Pequot were notified that the investigation had been closed and no action would be taken against them. ==Compensation== While CEO of Morgan Stanley in 2006, Mack earned a total compensation of $41,399,010, which included a base salary of $800,000, stocks granted of $36,179,923, and options granted of $4,019,934.{{cite web|title=Executive Compensation: 2007 Annual Comp.: John J. Mack|url=http://equilar.com/CEO_Compensation/MORGAN_STANLEY_John_J._Mack.php|website=[[Equilar]]|accessdate=13 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208211348/http://equilar.com/CEO_Compensation/MORGAN_STANLEY_John_J._Mack.php|archivedate=8 February 2009|date=2007}} In 2008, he earned a total compensation of $1,235,097, which included a base salary of $800,000 and other compensation of $435,097. He did not receive any cash, stock, or options.{{cite web|title=Executive Compensation: 2008 Annual Comp.: John J. Mack|url=http://equilar.com/CEO_Compensation/MORGAN_STANLEY_John_J._Mack.php|website=[[Equilar]]|accessdate=13 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414092258/http://www.equilar.com/CEO_Compensation/Morgan_Stanley_John_J._Mack.php|archivedate=14 April 2009|date=2008}} In 2014, Mack defended the high fees paid to CEOs,{{cite news|last1=Taibbi|first1=Matt|title=Ex-Morgan Stanley Chief Jams Foot in Mouth, Complains of CEO Abuse|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/ex-morgan-stanley-chief-jams-foot-in-mouth-complains-of-ceo-abuse-20140213|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=13 February 2014}} saying on [[Bloomberg Television]] that the discussion of compensation was healthy, but that CEOs earn the rates.{{cite news|last1=Ruhle|first1=Stephanie|last2=Miller|first2=Matt|title=John Mack Says Wall Street Pay Debate Is `Healthy'|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/b/e0a7652e-a4bf-42f2-99a0-6b3cc276968a|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[Bloomberg Television]]|date=11 February 2014}} == Financial crisis of 2007–2009 == {{see also|Financial crisis of 2007–08}} Mack guided the firm through the [[financial crisis of 2008]],{{cite news|last1=Raghavan|first1=Anita|title=Citi's Bad Bet|url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/05/14/old-lane-citigroup-biz-cx_ar_0514oldlane.html|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]|date=14 May 2008}} building its capital position and overseeing the firm's conversion to a bank holding company. To stabilize the firm, he forged strategic alliances with China Investment Corporation and Mitsubishi UFJ Group and entered into a joint venture with Smith Barney, forming at the time the world's largest wealth management firm. During the crisis, Mack was advised by U.S. Treasury Secretary [[Hank Paulson]] and the head of the Federal Reserve Bank [[Ben Bernanke]] to sell Morgan Stanley. He has stated that during negotiations he was under considerable pressure from the president of the New York Federal Reserve, [[Tim Geithner]], to sell or merge Morgan Stanley to one of his competitors such as [[JPMorgan Chase|JP Morgan]].{{cite news|last1=Craig|first1=Susanne|last2=McCracken|first2=Jeffrey|last3=Luccetti|first3=Aaron|last4=Kelly|first4=Kate|title=The Weekend That Wall Street Died|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123051066413538349|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=29 December 2008}} Mack saw this as being contrary to the interests of Morgan Stanley shareholders and employees, similar to the demise of [[Bear Stearns]] in a forced sale to JP Morgan for $2 per share, (the deal was later revised to $10 a share), and insisted on finding other sources of financing instead.{{cite web|title=John Mack on Saving Morgan Stanley, Inside the Bunker |publisher=[[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]]|date=October 14, 2009 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R9sQtmPAYO0 |format= [[Flash Video]] (26:22) |accessdate=May 19, 2010}} == Board memberships == * [[New York-Presbyterian Hospital]]: Chairman of the Board of Trustees{{cite news|last1=Matheson|first1=Sarah|title=NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Breaks Ground for New Emergency Department|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/311415-new-york-presbyterian-hospital-breaks-ground-for-morgan-stanley-adult-emergency-room/|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[Epoch Times]]|date=7 October 2013}} * [[Duke University]]: Board of Trustees * University Hospital of Columbia University: Board member * University Hospital of Cornell University: Board member * [[IMG (company)|IMG]]: Director * [[Bloomberg Family Foundation]]: Board member * Business Council: Member * Business Roundtable: Member * [[China Investment Corporation]]: International Advisory Council * Mayor of [[Beijing]]: International Business Leaders Advisory Council * [[Monetary Authority of Singapore]]: International Advisory Panel * [[Partnership for New York City]]: Executive committee, Director * November 2011: Rev Worldwide: Board of directors{{cite news|last1=Philbin|first1=Brett|title=Deal Journal: John Mack Is Finding His Next Act|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2011/11/09/john-mack-is-finding-his-next-act/|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=9 November 2011}} * 2012: [[Lending Club|LendingClub]]: Board member{{cite news|last1=Campbell|first1=Dakin|title=Ex-Morgan Stanley CEO John Mack Joins LendingClub Board|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-04-12/ex-morgan-stanley-ceo-john-mack-joins-lendingclub-board|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[Business Week]]|date=12 April 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120413033048/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-04-12/ex-morgan-stanley-ceo-john-mack-joins-lendingclub-board|archivedate=13 April 2012}} == Philanthropy == Mack has donated to various entities through the Christy and John Mack Foundation, formerly known as C.J. Mack Foundation: * 1999: [[Duke University]]: $10 million to support various initiatives{{cite news|last1=Stroup|first1=Katherine|title=Couple contributes $10-million donation to Campaign for Duke|url=http://www.dukechronicle.com/article/1999/02/couple-contributes-10-million-donation-campaign-duke|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[The Chronicle (Duke University)|The Chronicle]]|date=26 February 1999}} * 2004: [[Duke University]]: $10 million to support integrative medicine{{cite news|last1=Duke Medicine News and Communications|title=C.J. Mack Foundation Gives $10 Million to Duke Center for Integrative Medicine|url=http://corporate.dukemedicine.org/news_and_publications/news_office/news/7393|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=Duke Medicine|date=30 January 2004}} * 2005: [[United States Naval Academy|United States Naval Academy Foundation]]: Endowment to support the Admiral [[Frank Bowman]] [http://www.usna.edu/BowmanProgram/ Scholar Program] * 2007: [[Shaw University]]: $5 million to support academic scholarships to this historically black college{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=David|title=Mack, wife donate $5M to Shaw University|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20070319/FREE/70319014/mack-wife-donate-5m-to-shaw-university|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[Crains New York Business]]|date=19 March 2007}} == In media == Mack earned the nickname "Mack the Knife" for his cost-cutting prowess while managing the fixed income division at Morgan Stanley, and he lived up to his billing at CSFB, where he cut 10,000 jobs and returned the bank to profitability.{{cite news|last1=Saigol|first1=Lina|title=‘Mack the Knife’ brings fearsome reputation to new role|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d9a8b080-d335-11e2-b3ff-00144feab7de.html|accessdate=12 November 2015|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=12 June 2013}} Mack was portrayed in the [[HBO]] film ''[[Too Big to Fail (film)|Too Big to Fail]]'' by [[Tony Shalhoub]] and in the [[BBC]] film ''[[The Last Days of Lehman Brothers]]'' by [[Henry Goodman]]. His career is also covered in detail in a 2007 book by Patricia Beard, ''[[Blue Blood and Mutiny: The Fight for the Soul of Morgan Stanley]]''. == Selected interviews == * Mack, John. "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R9sQtmPAYO0 Wharton Leadership Lecture: John Mack on Saving Morgan Stanley, Inside the Bunker.]" ''Knowledge at Wharton.'' University of Pennsylvania. October 14, 2009.{{cite news|title=Inside the Bunker: CEO John Mack on Saving Morgan Stanley|url=http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/inside-the-bunker-ceo-john-mack-on-saving-morgan-stanley/|accessdate=13 November 2015|work=[[University of Pennsylvania]]|date=14 October 2009}} * Mack, John and [[Hank Paulson]]. "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XoSMXx83oxk Mack, Paulson full interview.]" ''CNN Money.'' NYU Stern School of Business. March 2010. * [[Charlie Rose|Rose, Charlie]]. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20151117014210/http://charlierose.com/watch/50116477 Zhou Wenzhong; John Mack, Chairman, Morgan Stanley; Kenneth Roth on Human Rights in China; An appreciation of Reynolds Price.]" ''[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]].'' January 20, 2011. Interview starts at 25:30. == Personal life == Mack is married to Christy Mack (née King). They have three children.{{cite web|title=Board of Visitors: Christy King Mack, P’99, ‘01|url=http://dukeforward.dukemedicine.org/learn-more/board-of-visitors/christy-king-mack/|website=Duke biatchUniversity|accessdate=12 November 2015}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * United States. {{Infobox Politician | name = Kay Waldo Barnes | image = | office = [[List of mayors of Kansas City, Missouri|52nd]] Mayor of [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] | term_start = May 1999 | term_end = May 2007 | predecessor = [[Emanuel Cleaver]] | successor = [[Mark Funkhouser]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1938|3|30|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[St. Joseph, Missouri]], U.S. | alma_mater = [[University of Kansas]],
[[University of Missouri–Kansas City]] | occupation = Senior Director for University Engagement at [[Park University]] | spouse = | residence = [[Kansas City, Missouri]] | religion = }} '''Kay Waldo Barnes''' (born March 30, 1938) is a former two-term [[mayor]] of [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. She was the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee for {{ushr|Missouri|6|}} ([https://web.archive.org/web/20080619003650/http://nationalatlas.gov/printable/images/preview/congdist/mo06_109.gif map]) of the [[United States House of Representatives]] in the 2008 election against [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] incumbent [[Sam Graves]]. ==Biography== A native of [[St. Joseph, Missouri]], she earned a B.S. degree in secondary education from the [[University of Kansas]] and a masters in secondary education from the [[University of Missouri–Kansas City]].{{cite news|url=http://www.fortmilltimes.com/124/story/306466.html |title=Bio information on Barnes, Graves |publisher=[[Fort Mill Times]] |date=September 30, 2008 |first= |last= |accessdate=2008-10-17 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} She was president of ''Kay Waldo, Inc.'', a human resources development firm until her retirement. She is a [[cousin]] of famous [[journalist]] [[Walter Cronkite]].[http://www2.ljworld.com/news/2004/may/09/cronkite_wins_truman/ Cronkite wins Truman neighbor award] ''Lawrence Journal-World'', May 9, 2004 ==Career== In 1974, she was one of the first two women on the Jackson County Legislature. She was elected to the Kansas City council in 1979. Barnes was the first female mayor of Kansas City. Mayor Barnes has received the most credit for her work in improving [[Downtown Kansas City]] and working for beginning the revitalization of the urban core. She is also credited with the [[Sprint Center]] arena in Kansas City that opened on October 10, 2007. She was first elected mayor on her birthday in 1999, and re-elected for a second term in 2003. She was succeeded as mayor of Kansas City on May 1, 2007, when [[Mark Funkhouser]] took office. At Missouri Democratic functions, beginning in April, 2007, Mayor Barnes made it clear that she was seriously considering a run for [[U.S. House elections, 2008|Congress in 2008]], and on May 14, 2007, she officially announced her candidacy. She was endorsed by [[Emily's List]].[http://www.emilyslist.org/candidates/kay_barnes/ Kay Barnes, U.S. House, MO] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513002208/http://emilyslist.org/candidates/kay_barnes/ |date=2008-05-13 }} ''Emily's List'' On August 5, 2008, Barnes won against Ali Allon Sherkat in the Democratic primary with 84.5% of the vote.[http://www.sos.mo.gov/enrweb/raceresults.asp?eid=195&oid=44676&arc= U.S. Representative - District 6] ''Missouri Secretary of State'' election results In late 2007, Barnes announced she would run in the Democratic primary for Missouri's 6th congressional district, held by four-term [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Sam Graves]]. She had spent most of her life in the district; she lives in the 6th's portion of Kansas City, and grew up in St. Joseph, the largest city entirely in the 6th. Although the race was initially thought to be competitive, Barnes was soundly defeated, taking only 37 percent of the vote. She even lost the district's share of Kansas City. She is Senior Director for University Engagement at [[Park University]].{{cite news | url=https://www.park.edu/news/kay-barnes-new-role/ | title=Barnes Appointed to New Position at Park University | publisher=[[Park University]] | date=July 2, 2018 | first= | last= | accessdate=2018-07-03 }} ==See also== *[[United States House of Representatives elections in Missouri, 2008#District 6]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{CongLinks | congbio= | votesmart=104458 | fec=H8MO06068 | congress= }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080410130246/http://www.opensecrets.org/races/summary.asp?cycle=2008&id=MO06 Missouri District 6 campaign contributions] at [[OpenSecrets.org]] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before = [[Emanuel Cleaver]] | title = [[List of mayors of Kansas City|Mayors of Kansas City, Missouri]] | years = 1999-2007 | after=[[Mark Funkhouser]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barnes, Kay}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Politicians from St. Joseph, Missouri]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Mayors of Kansas City, Missouri]] [[Category:Missouri Democrats]] [[Category:University of Kansas alumni]] [[Category:Women mayors of places in Missouri]] [[Category:Women in Missouri politics]]

{{Infobox settlement | official_name = Marquis Industrial | other_name = | settlement_type = Neighbourhood | motto = | image_skyline = | image_caption = | pushpin_map = <!-- the name of a location map as per http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Location_map --> | pushpin_label_position = <!-- the position of the pushpin label: left, right, top, bottom, none --> | pushpin_map_caption = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{CAN}} | subdivision_type1 = Province | subdivision_name1 = {{SK}} | subdivision_type2 = City | subdivision_name2 = Saskatoon | subdivision_type3 = Suburban Development Area | subdivision_name3 = [[North Industrial SDA, Saskatoon|North Industrial SDA]] | subdivision_type4 = Neighbourhood | subdivision_name4 = Marquis Industrial | government_footnotes = | government_type = Municipal (Ward 5) | leader_title = Administrative body | leader_name = [[Saskatoon City Council]] | leader_title1 = Councillor | leader_name1 = [[Saskatoon City Council#Ward 5|Randy Donauer]] | established_title = Annexed | established_date = 1980-1984 | area_footnotes = | area_total_km2 = | population_as_of = 2006 | population_footnotes = | population_note = | population_total = | population_density_km2 = auto | population_blank1_title = [[Median household income|Average Income]] | population_blank1 = <!-- [[Canadian dollar|$]] --> | timezone = CST | utc_offset = -6 | timezone_DST = | utc_offset_DST = | coordinates = {{coord|52|11|33|N|106|40|53|W|region:CA-SK|display=inline,title}} | elevation_footnotes = <!--for references: use<ref> </ref> tags--> | elevation_m = | postal_code_type = <!-- enter ZIP code, Postcode, Post code, Postal code... --> | postal_code = | area_code = | footnotes = [[List of neighbourhoods in Saskatoon]] }} '''Marquis Industrial''' is an [[industrial park]] located in the [[North Industrial SDA, Saskatoon|North Industrial SDA]] Suburban Development Area of [[Saskatoon]], [[Saskatchewan]]. Industrial parks are usually located close to [[transport]] facilities, especially where [[intermodal freight transport|more than one transport modalities]] coincide. [[Saskatchewan Highway 11|Sk Hwy 11]], and [[Saskatchewan Highway 12|Sk Hwy 12]] are all accessed directly from Marquis Industrial. The [[Saskatoon John G. Diefenbaker International Airport]] is west of the [[Saskatchewan Highway 11|Sk Hwy 11]] [[Saskatchewan Highway 12|Sk Hwy 12]] concurrency along Idylwyld Drive.
==Geography== The land was annexed from the [[rural municipality]] of [[Corman Park No. 344, Saskatchewan|Corman Park]] between 1975 and 1984 and 1990-1994. In 2005 land was annexed for Akzo (Marquis Industrial).<ref>{{cite web | title = Populace Spring 2006 | url = http://www.saskatoon.ca/org/city_planning/resources/populace_newsletter/Populace_Spring_2006.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-12 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071201065317/http://www.saskatoon.ca/org/city_planning/resources/populace_newsletter/Populace_Spring_2006.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-12-01}}</ref> The Marquis Industrial subdivision is along two major trucking routes. [[Saskatchewan Highway 11|Sk Hwy 11]] to [[Prince Albert, Saskatchewan|Prince Albert]] via [[Warman, Saskatchewan|Warman]], and [[Saskatchewan Highway 12|Sk Hwy 12]] to [[Blaine Lake]] via [[Martensville, Saskatchewan|Martensville]] mark the western boundary. Commercial and industrial enterprises along both sides of 71st Street are the northern perimeter of the industrial park.
From the 1980s until recently, the portion of Marquis Industrial east of the rail line and north of the [[Silverwood Heights, Saskatoon|Silverwood Heights]] community was demarcated as '''Silverwood Industrial'''.
==Economy== The Marquis Industrial park is a mix of commercial and industrial concerns. Merlin-Ford Lincoln is a car dealership located in the Marquis Industrial area and has not relocated to the [[auto mall]] in the Stonegate subdivision. Cover-all Building Systems, Case-New Holland agricultural machinery manufacturer, Peavey Mart, Maple Leaf pork processing facility, Akzo Nobel Chemicals Ltd., Beachcomber Hot Tubs, Centennial Plumbing and Heating are a few of the Marquis Industrial businesses. The Saskatoon Correctional Centre also is located in the Marquis Industrial park. NORAC Systems International Inc. opened their {{convert|2.87|acre|m2|adj=on}} land, [[Canadian dollar|$]]2.5-million industrial plant in 2007.<ref>{{cite web | title = Business invests ... Saskatoon wins!(SASKATOON UPDATE)(Company overview) Industry & Business Article - Research, News, Information, Contacts, Divisions, Subsidiaries, Business Associations | url = http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-6300664/Business-invests-Saskatoon-wins-SASKATOON.html | accessdate = 2008-05-12}}</ref>
In the Marquis Industrial subdivision are 1092 full-time employees and 24 part-time employees.<ref>{{cite web | title = Final Report 2005 | url = http://www.saskatoon.ca/org/transit/strategicplan/FinalReport2005.pdf | accessdate = 2008-05-12}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Transportation== Until recently, the area was primarily accessed via Wanuskewein Road and Miller Avenue from the south and north and 71st Street from the west. An extension of Marquis Drive has now provided the region with its major road access, and in 2013 the city approved plans for a north commuter bridge off the east end of Marquis that will connect to an extension of [[McOrmond Drive]] from the east, providing a major commuter link between Marquis Industrial and the residential communities in northeast and east Saskatoon. The bridge is not, however, being considered a truck route.

wind and solar energy | revenue = {{profit}} [[€]] ~650 million (core activity - 2008) | num_employees = ~3000 (2008) | homepage = [http://www.martifer.com www.martifer.com] }} '''Martifer''' is a family group based in [[Oliveira de Frades]], [[Portugal]], with over 3,000 employees, focusing its activity on the [[metalworking|metal construction]] and [[renewable energy]] areas. The company launched its first operations in 1990 in the metal structure industry. In 2004, it entered the renewables business, leveraging know-how from the metal construction operation to develop the energy equipment division. Martifer is market leader in [[Iberia]] for metal construction, and aims to become the top player in other specific markets, namely [[Europe]] and [[Angola]]. In renewable energies, Martifer would like to become established as an integrated producer of turn-key solutions for the wind and solar segments. Furthermore, within renewable energies, Martifer operates as a promoter of electricity generation projects, with a portfolio of holdings in projects at different phases of development. Martifer SGPS, SA is the Group’s holding company and has been listed on the Euronext Lisbon since June 2007. In 2008, its core activity operating revenues reached EUR 650 million. The main shareholder structure is made up of the founding partners, through I’M SGPS, S.A., and the [[Mota Engil|Mota-Engil Group]], both control approximately 80% of the company.http://www.martifer.com/ In June 2009, Martifer and [[Hirschfeld Wind Energy Solutions]], a part of [[Hirschfeld Industries]] in [[Texas]], United States, announced a [[Joint venture]] for the manufacture of [[wind towers]] and related components in the United States. The project cost was estimated to cost $40 million US dollars to build a new facility in San Angelo, Texas. Production was originally expected to reach a capacity of 400 towers a year by 2013.[http://www.hirschfeld.com/news_item.asp?ID=18 Hirschfeld Industries press release] June 19, 2009 However, the operation was unable to compete effectively in the very difficult pricing environment for wind towers in the 2009-2011 time frame and the investment failed to reach its objectives. In July 18, 2012, Hirschfeld announced that it had acquired the remaining 50 percent of the joint venture from Martifer for a small cash payment, and as of 2014, had converted the plant to build steel bridge structures. The last wind tower was produced there in 2012.{{cite news|last=Waller|first=Matthew|title=Martifer leaves wind tower plant: Hirschfeld buys out stake in company|url=http://www.gosanangelo.com/news/2012/jul/18/martifer-out-of-hirschfeld-partnership/|accessdate=July 19, 2012|newspaper=San Angelo Standard Times|date=July 19, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Martifer Out of Hirschfeld Joint Venture|url=http://stateofthedivision.blogspot.com/2012/07/martifer-out-of-hirschfeld-joint.html|work=State of the Division Blog|accessdate=July 19, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Waller|first=M|title=Martifer leaves wind tower plant|url=http://www.power-eng.com/news/2012/07/19/martifer-leaves-wind-tower-plant.html|work=Power Engineering|publisher=PennWell|accessdate=July 19, 2012}} == History == The company was founded by two brothers, Carlos Martins and Jorge Martins in Oliveira de Frades, Central Portugal,. The enterprise has started with 18 employees. Today the group has worldwide 3,000 employees. Subsidiaries are in Spain (1999), [[Poland]] (2003), [[Romania]] (2005), [[Czech Republic]] (2005), [[Slovakia]] (2005), Germany (2005), [[Brazil]] (2006) and [[Angola]] (2006). == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.martifer.com/ Official Website] * [http://www.euronext.com/landing/indexMarket-18812-PT.html NYSE Euronext] * {{OpenCorp|Martifer}} [[Category:Companies of Portugal]] [[Category:Companies established in 1990]] [[Category:Renewable energy technology companies]] [[Category:Portuguese brands]]

{{Infobox person |name =Mary Eleanor Brackenridge |image = |alt = | birth_name = | birth_date={{birth date|1837|03|07}} | birth_place=[[Warrick County, Indiana|Warrick County]], [[Indiana]] | death_date={{death date and age|mf=yes|1924|02|14|1837|07|07}} | death_place=San Antonio, Texas |resting_place =Brackenridge Family Cemetery [[Jackson County, Texas|Jackson County]], Texas | resting_place_coordinates = {{Coord|28.94860|-96.54000|type:landmark_region:US-TX|display=inline|name=George Washington Brackenridge grave}} | ethnicity = | education = | alma_mater =Anderson Female Seminary | spouse= | known_for=Founded [[Woman's Club of San Antonio]]
Women's Suffrage
Regent [[Texas Woman's University|TWU]] | children = | residence= | religion= |}} '''Mary Eleanor Brackenridge''' (March 7, 1837 – February 14, 1924) was one of three women on the first board of regents at [[Texas Woman's University]], the first women in the state of Texas to sit on a governing board of any university. She was active in women's clubs and was a co-founder of the [[Woman's Club of San Antonio]]. Brackenridge was a leader in Texas suffrage organizations and helped get the [[19th Amendment to the United States Constitution]] passed. She was the first woman in San Antonio to register to vote. Although it's the Brackenridge name in Texas that is associated with wealth, philanthropy and achievement, Brackenridge qualified as a member of the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]] through her mother's lineage. ==Background== Mary Eleanor Brackenridge was born March 7, 1837 in [[Warrick County, Indiana]]. She was the eldest daughter in a family of eight children born to John Adams Brackenridge and his wife Isabella Helena McCullough. She is often referred to as Eleanor, or M. Eleanor, in historical documentation. The family moved to [[Jackson County, Texas]] in 1853, but she remained behind and graduated in 1855 from Anderson's Female Academy in [[New Albany, Indiana|New Albany]], Indiana.{{cite book|last=Logan|first=Mary Simmerson Cunningham|title=The Part Taken by Women in American History|year=1911|publisher=The Perry-Nalle Publishing Company|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hnIEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA420&dq=new+albany+indiana+%22Anderson%27s+Female+Seminary+%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xJe3UNGcArCUigLwoIDoBQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=new%20albany%20indiana%20%22Anderson%27s%20Female%20Seminary%20%22&f=false|author2=Logan, John A|page=420}} Her father died during the [[Civil War (United States)|Civil War]], and she and her mother later moved into the [[San Antonio]] home of her brother [[George Washington Brackenridge]]. He appointed her director of the [[San Antonio National Bank]] and the [[San Antonio Loan and Trust]], both institutions established by him. In San Antonio, she was active in the [[Women's Christian Temperance Union]] (WCTU), the [[Order of the Eastern Star]] and the [[Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.)|Presbyterian Church]]. She was a member of the Texas Mothers' Congress, a predecessor to the Texas Congress of Parents and Teachers (Texas PTA).{{cite web|last=Schmidt|first=May|title=Texas Congress of Parents and Teachers (Texas PTA)|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/kat02|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} In 1906, Brackenridge was named vice-president of the San Antonio Health Protection Association, formed to combat [[tuberculosis]] in the city.{{cite book|title=Medical Insurance and Health Conservation, Volume 16|year=1906|publisher=Kress & Owen Co.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=trxXAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA188&dq=women%27s+club+of+san+antonio+%22eleanor+brackenridge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=e6i6ULjkKqvFiwLD6YC4DA&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=women%27s%20club%20of%20san%20antonio%20%22eleanor%20brackenridge%22&f=false|page=188}}{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=A. Elizabeth|title=Mary Eleanor Brackenridge|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbr04|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} ==Women's suffrage== Her achievements through women's clubs and suffrage organizations lived beyond her lifetime. Most notably, the Woman's Club of San Antonio and Texas Woman's University are still active today. Through these efforts, she was able to promote the welfare and advancement of women and children. In 1911, she made a study of the state's legal code and published a pamphlet entitled ''The Legal Status of Texas Women''. The WCTU and women's organizations often worked hand-in-hand for suffrage. The Texas Woman Suffrage Association was begun in 1903 in Houston by [[Annette Finnigan]] who served as its first president. When Finnigan left Texas, the organization stalled. It was fused with new energy in 1913 and was renamed the Texas Equal Suffrage Association. At the organization's convention in San Antonio, Brackenridge was named its president. Within two years, the organization had twenty-one chapters.{{cite book|last=Cullen|first=David O'Donald|title=The Texas Left: The Radical Roots of Lone Star Liberalism|year=2010|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|isbn=978-1-60344-189-6|pages=134–137|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AZNEAqTauREC&pg=PA135&dq=suffrage+%22Eleanor+Brackenridge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=L5u6UKq9A8WJiwLt74DQAw&ved=0CDUQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=suffrage%20%22Eleanor%20Brackenridge%22&f=false|author2=Wilkison, Kyle Grant}} On June 28, 1919, Texas became the first southern state to ratify the passage of the [[19th Amendment to the United States Constitution]], giving women the right to vote.{{cite web|title=Texas Senate ratifies women's right to vote|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/day-by-day/30244|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} Brackenridge became the first woman in San Antonio to register to vote. ===The Woman's Club of San Antonio=== On October 1, 1898, the [[Woman's Club of San Antonio]] was organized by Brackenridge and [[Marin B. Fenwick]].,{{cite web|last=Cottrell|first=Debbie Mauldin|title=Marin B. Fenwick|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/ffeen|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} a precursor of other similar civic and social organizations in the city. The organization was the vanguard of Texas women's clubs in promoting [[Women's suffrage in the United States|women's suffrage]]. Brackenridge served as the organization's president for the first seven years of its existence. There were eighteen charter members when the organization began.{{cite web|title=A Guide to the Woman's Club of San Antonio Records, 1892–2004|url=http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/utsa/00051/utsa-00051.html|publisher=[[University of Texas at San Antonio|UTSA]] Libraries|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} The club's organization included departments that focused on specific needs of women and children. The departments represented needs such as legal issues, employment for women, health needs, community activism, and educational needs. In 1905, the club established the Isabella H. Brackenridge Scholarship for students at [[University of Texas Medical Branch]].{{cite book|title=The University of Texas Record, Volume 6|year=1905|publisher=[[The University of Texas]]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_CrOAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA65&dq=%22woman%27s+club+of+san+antonio%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=L3y6ULOMG4WJiwLFs4EQ&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=%22woman%27s%20club%20of%20san%20antonio%22&f=false|page=65}} On July 8, 1926, the organization bought the [[David J. and May Bock Woodward House]] and currently uses it as their headquarters.{{cite web|title=David J. and May Bock Woodward House|url=https://atlas.thc.state.tx.us/Details/5029005890|publisher=[[Texas Historical Commission]]|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} The Woodward house was placed on the [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Bexar County, Texas]] February 16, 1996. ===Texas Woman's University=== Texas Woman's University (TWU) came into being as a result of lobbying efforts of individual proponents working in conjunction with the [[Women's Christian Temperance Union]] (WCTU), Texas Federation of Women's Clubs (TFWC), Texas Woman's Press Association (TWPA). and the [[The National Grange of the Order of Patrons of Husbandry|Grange]]. The Girls Industrial College was created by House Bill 35 of the [[Twenty-seventh Texas Legislature]]. It was signed into law by Texas Governor [[Joseph D. Sayers]] on April 6, 1901. The name was changed in 1905 to the College of Industrial Arts. In 1934 the school was renamed as Texas College for Women, and renamed to its current [[Texas Woman's University]] in 1957. The school's first board of regents was appointed by Governor Sayers in 1902. The three influential women who served on that first board were instrumental in the establishment of the university: Mary Eleanor Brackenridge, Texas WCTU president [[Helen M. Stoddard]] and [[Eliza S. R. Johnson]], wife of State Senator Cone Johnson and daughter of [[Elijah Sterling Clack Robertson]].{{cite web|title=TWU Timeline|url=http://www.twu.edu/twunews/twu-timeline.asp|publisher=Texas Woman's University|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} They were the first women to sit on a governing board of any university in Texas.{{cite web|last=Thompson|first=Joyce|title=Texas Woman's University|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/kct37|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} Brackenridge served as a regent until her death. The Mary Eleanor Brackenridge Club at TWU was established to help broaden the cultural awareness of its members.{{cite book|last=Gold|first=David|title=Rhetoric at the Margins: Revising the History of Writing Instruction in American Colleges, 1873–1947|year=2008|publisher=Southern Illinois University Press|isbn=978-0-8093-2834-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZXOhvd4A4-EC&pg=PA94&dq=texas+women%27s+university+%22eleanor+brackenridge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=DKS6UNesA4iwigLQz4C4BQ&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=texas%20women%27s%20university%20%22eleanor%20brackenridge%22&f=false|page=94}} The Stoddard Domitory and the Brackenridge Dormitory were the first two on-campus residence halls at TWU.{{cite web|title=First Domitories|url=http://www.twu.edu/downloads/library/3-11.pdf|publisher=Texas Woman's University|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} The current Mary Eleanor Brackenridge Student Union at TWU is named in her honor.{{cite web|title=Mary Eleanor Brackenridge Student Union|url=http://www.twu.edu/student-union/|publisher=Texas Woman's University|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} ==Family lineage and DAR membership== Mary Eleanor Brackenridge was a member of the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]], qualified by an ancestor through her maternal lineage. The Brackenridge name in Texas descended from [[Scotch-Irish American|Scotch-Irish]] Robert Breckenridge Sr., who emigrated from [[Northern Ireland]] with his brother Alexander c1730. Alexander, whose descendents spell their name [[Breckinridge family|Breckinridge]], moved to [[Virginia]].{{cite web|title=Breckinridge|url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/breckinridge.html#RQ603KDX7|publisher=Political Graveyard|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} Robert Sr., whose descendants spell their name either Breckenridge or Brackenridge, stayed in [[Cumberland County, Pennsylvania]]. Robert Jr. (c1735-c1779) was killed in an Indian raid. His son [[John Brackenridge (clergyman)|John Brackenridge]] ({{circa|1772}} – May 2, 1844) was raised in [[Washington, D.C.]],{{cite journal|title=Records|year=1922|volume=24|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m_07AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA123&dq=%22Rev.+John+Brackenridge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fi-yULbzEOnLigLu0oHICQ&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22Rev.%20John%20Brackenridge%22&f=false|page=123|publisher=Columbia Historical Society, Washington D.C.}} and was appointed [[Chaplain of the United States Senate]] in 1811.{{cite web|title=Senate Chaplain|url=https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/briefing/Senate_Chaplain.htm|publisher=United States Senate|accessdate=December 2, 2012}}{{cite book|last=Welk|first=Jesse W|title=The Real Lincoln: A Portrait|year=2003|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|isbn=978-0-8032-9822-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pMFlBVZtaWUC&pg=PA318&dq=%22Rev.+John+Brackenridge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9SyyUL_UFqnYigKP2ID4DA&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22Rev.%20John%20Brackenridge%22&f=false|author2=Burlingame, Michael|page=318|chapter=G.W. Brackenridge letter dated 15 Dec 1914}} His son John Adams Brackenridge was the father of Mary Eleanor Brackenridge.{{cite web|title=Breckenridge family history|url=http://www.billputman.com/Breckenridge.pdf|publisher=Bill Putman|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} John Adams Brackenridge (1800–1862) was a graduate of [[Princeton University]] and a politically active lawyer in [[Warrick County, Indiana]].{{cite journal|last=Raleigh|first=Eldora Minor|title=John A. Brackenridge|journal=Proceedings of the Southwest Indiana Historical Society|date=October 1922|volume=16|pages=60–66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M4VQAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA64&dq=brackenridge+%22james+h+bates%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=5sauUKyaNsiIiwLxiYCICw&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=brackenridge%20%22james%20h%20bates%22&f=false|publisher=Indiana Historical Commission}} Isabella Helena McCullough (1811–1886) married John Adams Brackenridge in 1827. Her maternal Scotch-Irish ancestor Rev. John Craig was from [[County Antrim]], [[Northern Ireland]]. Her father James McCullough was from [[Belfast]], Northern Island. The lineage of James McCullough's wife Mary Craig Grimes was the criteria for acceptance into the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]]. The parents of Mary Craig Grimes were William Grimes and Isabella Helena Baskin. Tracing the lineage through Isabella Helena Baskin, her grandparents were Charles Baskin and Mary Craig. The DAR certified that Charles Baskin (1741–1822) served during the [[American Revolutionary War]] under General Daniel Morgan.{{cite book|title=Lineage Book|year=1913|publisher=Daughters of the American Revolusion, Vol 37|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1WUZAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA186&dq=%22Mary+Eleanor+Brackenridge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xm23ULenOsy6yAGz1oGwAw&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22Mary%20Eleanor%20Brackenridge%22&f=false|page=186}}{{Find a Grave|24835429|Charles Baskin}} All of the eight children of John Adams and Isabella Brackenridge were born in Indiana. The family moved to Texas in 1853. Many family members are buried in the Brackenridge Family Cemetery in Jackson County, Texas.{{cite web|title=Brackenridge Family Cemetery |url=http://www.brackenridgepark.com/aboutus/cemetery.aspx |publisher=Brackenridge Recreation Complex |accessdate=December 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419122218/http://www.brackenridgepark.com/aboutus/cemetery.aspx |archivedate=April 19, 2012 |df= }} ===Brothers and sisters of Mary Eleanor Brackenridge=== Sometime after the death of her father in 1862, Eleanor and her mother Isabella moved into her brother George's home in San Antonio. He supported his mother for the rest of her life, and took care of Eleanor until his own death.{{cite journal|last=Garlock|first=Dave|title=UT was nearly the "University by the Lake"|journal=Texas Highways|issue=March 2012|url=http://www.texashighways.com/component/content/article?id=6397:speaking-of-texas-feud-of-the-ut-titans}} The siblings of Mary Eleanor Brackenridge were as follows: ====Brothers==== [[John Thomas Brackenridge]] (1828–1877), known to the family as Tom, gave up his Indiana law practice to join the family mercantile business in Texas. Tom served in the [[Confederate States Army]] under [[John B. Magruder]]. In 1877, he became president of First National Bank of Austin. Tom married twice, to E. R. Smith and to Mary E. Dupuy. He is buried in [[Oakwood Cemetery (Austin, Texas)|Oakwood Cemetery]] in Austin.{{Find a Grave|62659516|Maj J.T. Brackenridge}}{{cite web|title=John Thomas Brackenridge|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbr03|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} [[George Washington Brackenridge]] (1832–1920) was a philanthropist, businessman and the longest-serving Regent for the University of Texas. He donated much of his wealth and landholdings to benefit students. Brackenridge established two San Antonio banking institutions. He is the namesake and chief benefactor of [[Brackenridge Park]] in San Antonio, and the adjoining [[Mahncke Park, San Antonio|Mahncke Park]] was made possible through his donation of land. George never married, and is buried in the family cemetery in Jackson County.{{cite web|title=George Washington Brackenridge|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbr02|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} [[James M. Brackenridge]] (1834–1905) enlisted with the Confederate States Army, and afterwards became a judge in [[Travis County, Texas|Travis County]], Texas. He married Mattie Owen and is buried in Oakwood Cemetery in Austin.{{Find a Grave|62658105|James M. Brackenridge}}{{cite book|last=Daniell|first=Lewis E|title=Personnel of the Texas state government|year=1898|publisher=State of Texas|pages=394, 385|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fTEEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA394&dq=%22James+M.+Brackenridge%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cYatUNbHBqStiAKQw4DQBA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22James%20M.%20Brackenridge%22&f=false}} [[Robert John Brackenridge]] (1839–1918) served in the Confederate States Army in his brother Tom's unit in Texas. Captured and imprisoned, he was paroled through the political influence of brother George. Brackenridge Hospital{{cite web|title=Robert John Brackenridge|url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=25779|publisher=Historical Marker Database|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} in Austin is named in recognition of his fund raising efforts which helped build the hospital.{{cite web|last=Marten|first=James A|title=Brackenridge Hospital|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/sbb02|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} He was married to Mary T. Lyons and is buried with her in the Oakwood Cemetery Annex.{{Find a Grave|26212478|Robert J. Brackenridge}}{{cite web|last=Kemp|first=Elizabeth J|title=Robert J. Brackenridge|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbr05|work=Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} ====Sisters==== Lenora Helena Brackenridge Mathews (1842–1918) was a civic activist who helped establish a local chapter of the [[American Red Cross]]. She married Erastus Allen Mathews and is buried in the family cemetery.{{cite web|title=E.A. Matthews, Civil War Soldier, and Ophelia Emily Garrett|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~matthews/Loderick_Matthews_2.htm|publisher=Ancestry.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} Elizabeth Ann Brackenridge (1845–1847), known as Lizzie, is buried in Indiana.{{cite web|title=Cemetery Section 8|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~txjacks2/Cemeteries/Brackenridge/BrackenCemeteryInfoSection8.htm|publisher=Ancestry.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} Elizabeth Ann Brackenridge (1848–1856), known as Lillie, is buried in the family cemetery.{{cite web|title=Brackenridge Cemetery|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~txjacks2/Cemeteries/Brackenridge/BrackenCemeteryInfoSection2.htm|publisher=Ancestry.com|accessdate=December 2, 2012}} ==Death== Mary Eleanor Brackenridge never married. She died of a [[cerebral hemorrhage]] on February 14, 1924 and is buried in the family cemetery in Jackson County, Texas. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}} ==External links== *[http://www.twu.edu/ Texas Woman's University] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120923212455/http://www.thewomansclubsa.org/about.html The Woman's Club of San Antonio official site] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brackenridge, Mary Eleanor}} [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1924 deaths]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American feminists]] [[Category:American suffragists]] [[Category:History of women's rights in the United States]] [[Category:People from San Antonio]] [[Category:People from Warrick County, Indiana]] [[Category:American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:American temperance activists]] [[Category:Activists from Texas]]

born July 23, 1957{{cite web|url=http://www.thedraftreview.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=5076|title=The Draft Review|first=Fine Line Websites & IT|last=Consulting|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}}), commonly known as either '''Nikos Galis''' ({{lang-el|Νίκος Γκάλης}}), or '''Nick Galis''', is a retired Greek American professional [[basketball]] player. He was named one of [[FIBA's 50 Greatest Players (1991)|FIBA's 50 Greatest Players]] in 1991, is an inaugural member of the [[FIBA Hall of Fame]]{{Cite web |url=http://www.halloffame.fiba.com/pages/eng/hof/indu/play/2007/p/lid_17904_newsid/19959/bio.html/# |title=FIBA Hall Of Fame Class of 2007 |access-date=2007-06-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707073724/http://www.halloffame.fiba.com/pages/eng/hof/indu/play/2007/p/lid_17904_newsid/19959/bio.html/# |archive-date=2007-07-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }} and was chosen as one of the [[50 Greatest EuroLeague Contributors]] in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleague.net/item/24016|title=Euroleague official website, ''Experts decide European Club Basketball's 50 greatest contributors''}} Galis is widely regarded as one of [[Europe|Europe's]] greatest scorers to ever play the game, as well as one of the all-time greatest players in [[FIBA]] international basketball history.{{efn|SeePsarakis, Yannis, Fibaeurope.com, Nikos Galis - Europe's Greatest - Ever Scorer [http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_N27pw3E0IEQwyW1SY,jjq1.coid_TAEWX2DlJdkjxfsVfUULa3.articleMode_on.html]{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleague.net/features/voices/2011-2012/vladimir-stankovic/i/91124/nikos-gallis-a-scoring-machine|title=Nikos Gallis, a scoring machine|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/coid_TcU1iWLAI,EZ-oLXXo5xm2.articleMode_on.html|title=European Legends Pay Tribute To Galis - FIBA Europe|website=www.fibaeurope.com|accessdate=13 November 2018}}}} In 2017, he was inducted into the [[List of players in the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame|Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/story/_/id/19052994/tracy-mcgrady-bill-self-rebecca-lobo-headline-2017-basketball-hall-fame-class|title=McGrady, Self, Lobo headline 2017 HOF class|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018|date=April 2017}} Galis played the [[point guard]] position during his [[college basketball]] years at [[Seton Hall Pirates men's basketball|Seton Hall University]], but turned into a [[shooting guard]] as a [[professional sports|professional]]. He spent most of his career in [[Aris BC|Aris]], before having a late stint with [[Panathinaikos BC|Panathinaikos]]. He is the [[EuroLeague]]'s all-time leader in points per game (counting both [[FIBA Europe]] and [[Euroleague Basketball Company]] era games [[1958 FIBA European Champions Cup|1958 season]]–present), [[EuroLeague Top Scorer|leading the competition in scoring]] eight times. In [[EuroLeague|the premier European club scene]], he reached the [[EuroLeague Final Four]] on four occasions, three consecutive times with Aris ([[1988 EuroLeague Final Four|1988]], [[1989 EuroLeague Final Four|1989]], and [[1990 EuroLeague Final Four|1990]]), and another one with Panathinaikos ([[1994 EuroLeague Final Four|1994]]). An eight-time [[Greek Basket League|Greek league]] champion, Galis is the [[Greek Basketball Championship career statistical leaders#A National Category all-time stats leaders (since the 1963–64 season) (unofficial)|Greek Championship's unofficial all-time leading scorer]], in both career points scored and career scoring average, counting all league formats (since the 1963–64 season, [[Greek Basket League career stats leaders|official stats are recognized since the 1992–93 season]]). Galis led the senior [[Greece national basketball team|Greek national team]] to a [[EuroBasket]] gold medal in [[EuroBasket 1987|1987]], as well as to a EuroBasket silver medal in [[EuroBasket 1989|1989]], earning the [[FIBA EuroBasket MVP|tournament MVP]] honor in 1987, and being elected to the [[FIBA EuroBasket All-Tournament Team|All-EuroBasket Team]] four times. Among his myriad accomplishments, he holds the [[FIBA EuroBasket Records|EuroBasket record]] for highest career scoring average (31.2 points per game), and was [[FIBA EuroBasket Top Scorer|the leading scorer of four EuroBasket tournaments]] in [[EuroBasket 1983|1983]], [[EuroBasket 1987|1987]], [[EuroBasket 1989|1989]], and [[EuroBasket 1991|1991]]. In addition to that, he holds the [[FIBA World Cup]] [[FIBA World Cup records|record]] for highest career scoring average (33.5 points per game), as well as for most points ever scored in a single tournament, which he set at the [[1986 FIBA World Cup]]. Following the stunning success of the EuroBasket title in 1987, he won the [[Mr. Europa|Mr. Europa Player of the Year]] and the [[Euroscar Award|Euroscar]] awards the same year. Nicknamed "Iron Man",{{cite web|url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_wro9VQVdG7cxqdc3r6woH2.coid_OetsMywJJtcKppVVZ6xGT3.articleMode_on.html|title=Iron Man Galis - FIBA Europe|website=www.fibaeurope.com|accessdate=13 November 2018}} "Nick The Greek",{{cite web|url=http://www.interbasket.net/players/galis.htm|title=Nikos Galis, Greece - Player Profiles by Interbasket|website=www.interbasket.net|accessdate=13 November 2018}} and "The Gangster",[https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/nikosgalis/aris1.html&date=2009-10-25+23:42:53 Nikos Galis Aris] Galis is highly revered in [[Greece]], where he is considered by many to be the greatest national athlete the country has ever seen.{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fe/10/fwcm/event-guide/p/nid/41921/legend-bio.html|title=FIBA.com, Greece-Nick Galis.|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}} His years at Aris lifted [[Basketball in Greece|Greek basketball]] from relative obscurity, to global power status, with Galis being the figure that eventually inspired thousands of Greeks to take up the game.Maguire, Ken, Nytimes.com, Basking in a Fonder Farewell, 19 Years Later [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/14/sports/basketball/aris-honors-nick-galis-a-hero-of-greek-basketball.html?_r=0] ==Early life and high school== Galis was born in [[Union City, New Jersey]]. The child of a poor immigrant family, from the Greek islands of [[Rhodes]] and [[Nisyros]], Galis took up [[boxing]] in his early years, after his father, George Georgalis, who had also been a boxer in his youth. He was later persuaded to give up boxing by his mother, Stella Georgalis, who was terrified after each time that her son would return home from boxing training with a new facial injury. As a result, Galis started playing the sport of basketball instead of boxing. He attended [[Union Hill High School]], in Union City, where he also played high school basketball. ==College career== After high school, Galis enrolled at [[Seton Hall University]], where he played [[college basketball]] as a member of the [[Seton Hall Pirates men's basketball|Seton Hall Pirates]]. In his senior season, Galis saw his scoring average reach 27.5 points per game, which was third in the nation, behind [[Idaho State Bengals men's basketball|Idaho State's]] [[Lawrence Butler (basketball)|Lawrence Butler]] (30.1 points per game) and [[Indiana State Sycamores men's basketball|Indiana State's]] [[Larry Bird]] (28.6 points per game),{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Magic Keeps Bird In Hand |url=http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1123258/index.htm |work=Sports Illustrated |publisher= |date=1980-03-13 |accessdate= }} including a 48-point outburst against the [[Santa Clara Broncos men's basketball|University of Santa Clara]].{{cite web|url=http://graphics.fansonly.com/photos/schools/sacl/sports/m-baskbl/auto_pdf/cablecar-history-12300.pdf|title=Cable Car Classic Records.|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}} Also in his senior year of college, Galis won the [[Haggerty Award]] (the New York City metro area's best player award), and the [[Eastern College Athletic Conference]] Player of the Year award. The same year, he also played in the Pizza Hut All-American game, alongside Bird and [[Vinnie Johnson]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Galis and Larry Bird (Pizza Hut All American Game 1979) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PUdOiTjIcxo |work=Youtube|publisher= |date=2010-03-10 |accessdate= }} During his 4 year college career, Galis played in a total of 107 games and scored 1,651 points, for a career scoring average of 15.4 points per game.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/nick-galis-1.html|title=Nick Galis College Stats - College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com|website=College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com|accessdate=13 November 2018}} Galis' head coach at Seton Hall, [[Bill Raftery|Billy Raftery]], would later state that Galis was the best player he ever coached. While at Seton Hall, Galis was a good friend and roommate of [[Italian-American]] professional basketball player [[Dan Callandrillo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.app.com/story/sports/college/2017/09/08/insane-nick-galis-journey-naismith-hall-fame-took-off-seton-hall/646390001/|title=For 'insane' Nick Galis, journey to Naismith Hall of Fame took off at Seton Hall|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}} Galis was later inducted into the [[Seton Hall]] Athletic Hall of Fame, in 1991. ===College stats=== {{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/nick-galis-1.html|title=Nick Galis College Stats - College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com|website=College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com|accessdate=13 November 2018}} {| bgcolor="#f7f8ff" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; border: gray solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" | align="center"|'''Season''' | align="center"|'''Team''' | align="center"|'''Competition''' | align="center"|'''[[Games Played]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Field goal percentage|Field Goal%]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Free throw|Free Throw%]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Rebound (basketball)|Rebounds]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Assist (basketball)|Assists]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Points per game|Points]]''' |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" align=left |

|} ==Professional career== ===Boston Celtics=== After finishing his collegiate career in 1979, Galis signed with agent Bill Manon, who also managed [[Diana Ross]]. Manon did not have Galis work out with any [[NBA]] team.{{cite web|url=http://www.interbasket.net/players/galis.htm|title=Nikos Galis, Greece - Player Profiles by Interbasket|website=www.interbasket.net|accessdate=13 November 2018}} Galis was eventually selected by the [[Boston Celtics]] in the 4th round of the [[1979 NBA Draft]], 68th overall. Due to a severe ankle injury that Galis suffered during the [[Boston Celtics|Celtics]] preseason training camp of the [[1979–80 Boston Celtics season|1979–80 season]],{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/article/2017/08/31/euroleague-legend-nikos-galis-made-mark-five-greek-league-mvp-awards|title=2017 Hall of Fame: Euroleague legend, cast of NCAA standouts get their due - NBA.com|first=Scott|last=Howard-Cooper|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}} the franchise was no longer interested in offering him a contract because [[Gerald Henderson]] had taken his place on the team, and his injury would keep him out for the foreseeable future. Galis then decided to pursue a professional career in [[Greece]]'s top-tier level [[Greek Basket League|Basket League]]. Later, while still playing in Greece, he would be offered [[NBA]] contracts by the Celtics and the [[New Jersey Nets]]. However, he turned the offers down, because at the time, and until 1989, [[FIBA]] did not have [[professional sports|professional]] status, and consequently did not allow NBA players to compete at the [[national sports team|national team]] level. Since playing with the senior [[Greek national basketball team|Greek national team]] meant so much to him, he stayed in Greece. Celtics legend [[Red Auerbach]] later said that the single biggest mistake he ever made in his career was not keeping Galis.{{Cite web |url=http://turkey2010.fiba.com/pages/eng/fe/10/fwcm/event-guide/p/nid/41921/legend-bio.html# |title=Fiba official website, Tribute to Nikos Galis |access-date=2010-10-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101107144242/http://turkey2010.fiba.com/pages/eng/fe/10/fwcm/event-guide/p/nid/41921/legend-bio.html# |archive-date=2010-11-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.celticslife.com/2011/10/top-5-celtics-that-never-were-5-nick.html|title=Top 5 Celtics That Never Were- #5: Nick Galis|website=www.celticslife.com|accessdate=13 November 2018}} ===Aris Thessaloniki=== [[File:Nikos Galis Keith Williams.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Galis (on the right), and [[Keith Williams (basketball)|Keith Williams]] (on the left), during a [[EuroLeague]] [[1991–92 FIBA European League|1991–92 season]] game.]] After suffering an ankle injury in the [[Boston Celtics]] [[1979–80 Boston Celtics season|1979–80]] preseason training camp, which prevented him from receiving a contract with the Celtics, Galis made the move across the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]], and signed to play with [[Aris BC|Aris]] of [[Thessaloniki]], Greece, in 1979. [[Panathinaikos B.C.|Panathinaikos]] and [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]] had also shown some interest in signing the newcomer, but it was Aris' interest that was the most persuasive. His move to the country would eventually help Greek [[sports club|club]] basketball to reach a level of popularity that had never been previously imagined. Averaging more than 30 points per game every season, Galis was the indisputable leader of Aris. While playing alongside other great players at Aris such as [[Panagiotis Giannakis]] and [[Slobodan Subotić]] (who was known in Greece as Lefteris Soumpotits), Galis won 8 [[Greek Basket League|Greek League]] championships (7 of them consecutively, and 3 undefeated, in the years 1983, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, and 1991), 6 [[Greek Basketball Cup|Greek Cups]] (4 of them consecutively, in the years 1985, 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, and 1992), and led Aris to 3 consecutive appearances at the [[EuroLeague|FIBA European Champions' Cup]] (now called EuroLeague) [[EuroLeague Final Four|Final Four]] ([[1988 EuroLeague Final Four|'88]], [[1989 EuroLeague Final Four|'89]], and [[1990 EuroLeague Final Four|'90]]). In the one disappointment of an otherwise glittering career with Aris, all three of the FIBA European Champions' Cup Final Four appearances ended in defeat in the semifinals, thus depriving Galis of the opportunity to shine all the way on Europe's biggest club stage, at the [[EuroLeague Finals|FIBA European Champions' Cup Finals]]. The team's performances and general standard of play, however, won the hearts of most basketball fans in Greece. Indeed, cinemas and theaters in Greece would often reduce their admission prices on Thursday evenings, when Aris was playing games, as large segments of the country settled down to watch them on television. After a disappointing season in 1991–92, Galis was forced to leave Aris.Rabotas, G., ''Nikos Galis'', p. 137 The new management of the team, and the fact that the club was in decline, were the main causes for his departure. Galis, who adored the city of [[Thessaloniki]], had originally insisted on remaining in the club and playing for the team, as he believed that he still had a lot to offer the club. ===Panathinaikos Athens=== [[Image:Nikos Galis Panathinaikos 1992.jpg|right|thumb|160px|Galis with [[Panathinaikos B.C.|Panathinaikos]], during the 1992–93 season.]] Galis moved to [[Athens]] in the summer of 1992, to play with [[Panathinaikos B.C.|Panathinaikos]], and he was the player who then led the "Greens" to a club rebirth, after it had suffered through a long drought period, during which the historical team remained without titles. The previous season (1991–92) had been particularly disappointing for the club, with the team finishing eighth in the Greek league. As the team's [[Captain (sports)|captain]], Galis inspired the young players of Panathinaikos, such as [[Fragiskos Alvertis]] and [[Nikos Oikonomou]], and gradually brought back hope to the team's fans. So much so, as to the point that the club's then home arena, [[Glyfada Indoor Hall]], was always overcrowded. In that season (1992–93), Panathinaikos finished second in the [[Greek Basket League|Greek league]], and won the [[Greek Basketball Cup|Greek Cup]], which was the seventh Greek Cup title for Galis. The following season ([[1993–94 FIBA European League|1993–94]]), Galis was the FIBA European League (now called EuroLeague) [[EuroLeague Top Scorer|Top Scorer]] averaging 23.8 points per game in 21 games, and passer, averaging 4.7 assists per game, in 21 games. In the decisive game 3 of the EuroLeague quarterfinals, against the reigning [[EuroLeague|FIBA European League]] champions, [[Limoges CSP|Limoges]], Galis truly led Panathinaikos into a new club era, with their qualification to the [[1994 EuroLeague Final Four|1994 FIBA European League Final Four]], by scoring 30 points on 75% field goal shooting in the game. The "Greens" eventually finished in 3rd place in the FIBA European League that season, after losing in the semifinal, but it was still a success they had never reached before. Galis scored 30 points in the third place game against [[FC Barcelona Bàsquet|FC Barcelona]], leading all scorers in the game. In his third season in Panthinaikos ([[1994–95 FIBA European League|1994–95]]), Galis teamed up with [[Panagiotis Giannakis]] and [[Žarko Paspalj]], to make a strong effort to win the FIBA European League. Galis was the player who led Panathinaikos to the Top 16 group, as he prevented the elimination of Panathinaikos by [[Budivelnik Kiev]], with a team-high 23 points in the decisive second-leg victory. He was also the leader of the team in the [[Greek Basketball Cup|Greek Cup]] win against [[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos]], at [[Sporting Sports Arena]]. But Galis' career controversially ended on October 18, 1994,[http://www.gazzetta.gr/basket/a1/item/105797-Ηταν-απλά-ο-καλύτερος Gazetta.gr Ήταν απλά ο καλύτερος {{el icon}}.] a few games after the start of the Greek League 1994–95 season. [[Kostas Politis]], Panathinaikos' head coach at the time, chose not to include Galis in the starting line-up of a [[Greek Basket League|Greek League]] game against [[Ampelokipoi B.C.|Ambelokipi]]. Galis left the court, and never again returned to playing action.Rabotas, G., ''Nikos Galis'', p. 195 His last game in professional basketball, was as a player of Panathinaikos, in a game against [[Dafnis B.C.|AO Dafni]], on October 12, 1994. In the game, Galis scored 8 points in 35 minutes of playing time, as his team won in a blowout, 82–60. === Career pro club statistics === {{cite web|url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_Rrcja7ZFIJoKfuh7kQ,-F3.coid_TAEWX2DlJdkjxfsVfUULa3.articleMode_on.html|title=Nikos Galis – Europe's Greatest-ever Scorer - FIBA Europe|website=www.fibaeurope.com|accessdate=13 November 2018}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.basket.gr/archive/players/BestPlayer.asp?PlayerCode=101# |title=basket.gr Ονοματεπώνυμο: ΓΚΑΛΗΣ ΝΙΚΟΣ |language=el |access-date=2007-04-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070406075936/http://www.basket.gr/archive/players/BestPlayer.asp?PlayerCode=101# |archive-date=2007-04-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.sansimera.gr/biographies/279|title=Νίκος Γκάλης|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}} {| bgcolor="#f7f8ff" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; border: gray solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" | align="center"|'''Competition''' | align="center"|'''[[Games Played]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Point (basketball)|Points Scored]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Points per game|Scoring Average]]''' | align="center"|'''Ref.''' |- bgcolor="#EFEFEF" align=left |[[Greek Basket League|Greek League]] |

|} ==National team career== On 20 November 1983, while playing in an [[exhibition game]] at the Demetria Tournament '83, with the senior [[Greek national basketball team|Greek national basketball team]], against the [[North Carolina Tar Heels men's basketball|North Carolina Tar Heels]], at [[Alexandreio Melathron]], Greece's shooting guard Galis, while being guarded by North Carolina's [[shooting guard]], [[Michael Jordan]], scored 24 points during the game.{{cite web|url=https://www.eurohoops.net/en/nba-news/511452/nick-galis/|title=Nick Galis versus Michael Jordan - Eurohoops|date=9 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1VNv6gT1RWk|title=GREECE - NORTH CAROLINA (JORDAN vs GALIS, Oct. 20, 1983)|last=NickGalis Archive|date=7 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=13 November 2018|via=YouTube}} Galis next led the Greek national team to the [[EuroBasket 1987]] gold medal. Averaging 37.0 points per game during the tournament, he was named the [[FIBA EuroBasket MVP|MVP of the tournament]], after scoring 40 points in the final against the [[Soviet Union national basketball team]] and its legendary player, [[Šarūnas Marčiulionis]], for a 103–101 victory. Galis also led Greece to the second place at the [[EuroBasket 1989]], averaging 35.6 points per game. Galis is most remembered from that tournament, for a stunning effort against the Soviet team led by Marčiulionis, and its other star player, [[Arvydas Sabonis]], in the semifinal game. He scored 45 out of his team's 81 total points in a dramatic, last-gasp 81–80 victory.FIBA Europe official website on EuroBasket 1989 [http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_f43ulKJBGLcVnbH-aqLVu2.gameID_937-4-A-1.compID_qMRZdYCZI6EoANOrUf9le2.season_1989.roundID_937.teamID_.html FIBA Europe.com] The Greek team then settled for a second-place finish, after losing against the ever-dominant [[Yugoslavia national basketball team|Yugoslavian national basketball team]] in the tournament's final. With the senior men's Greek national team, Galis averaged 33.3 points per game at the [[EuroBasket 1983]], 33.5 points per game at the [[1986 FIBA World Championship]], 37.0 points per game at the [[EuroBasket 1987]], 35.6 points per game at the [[EuroBasket 1989]], and 32.4 points per game at the [[EuroBasket 1991]]. He won the gold medal at the EuroBasket 1987, and the silver medal at the EuroBasket 1989. He was [[FIBA EuroBasket Top Scorer|the leading scorer of the EuroBasket]] four times, was a four-time [[FIBA EuroBasket All-Tournament Team|All-EuroBasket Team]] member, and he was named [[FIBA EuroBasket MVP|the MVP of the EuroBasket 1987]]. He was also [[FIBA World Cup records|the leading scorer of the 1986 FIBA World Championship]], where he led all players in scoring average, with 33.5 points per game. In that tournament, he had a 53-point outburst against the [[Panama national basketball team|Panamanian national basketball team]]. In total, Galis played in 168 [[cap (sports)|games]] with the senior Greek national team, in which he scored a total of 5,129 points, for a scoring average of 30.5 points per game.{{cite web|url=http://basket.gr/index.php/playerview?playerid=101|title=Σελίδα Αθλητή|first=Super|last=User|website=Ελληνική Ομοσπονδία Καλαθοσφαίρισης|accessdate=13 November 2018}} ===Greek senior national team career statistics=== {| bgcolor="#f7f8ff" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" border="1" style="font-size: 95%; border: gray solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" | align="center"|'''Competition''' | align="center"|'''[[Games Played]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Point (basketball)|Points Scored]]''' | align="center"|'''[[Points per game|Scoring Average]]''' | align="center"|'''Ref.''' |-align=left |[[FIBA|FIBA International Competitions]]
